content.query:
-- OPENROWSET runs in the default master database. There are no objects like tables involved.
-- Simple
SELECT TOP 100 *
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/customers*.csv',
        FORMAT = 'CSV',
        PARSER_VERSION = '2.0',
        HEADER_ROW = TRUE
    ) AS [result]

-- With Mapping
SELECT TOP 100 *
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/customers*.csv',
        FORMAT = 'CSV',
        PARSER_VERSION = '2.0',
        HEADER_ROW = TRUE
    ) 
WITH (
    Id INT,
    FirstName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    LastName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    CompanyName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    StreetName VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    Number INT,
    City VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    Region VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8,
    Country VARCHAR(255) COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8
) AS [result]

-- Simple
SELECT doc
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/json/customers*/*.json',
        FORMAT = 'CSV',
        FIELDQUOTE = '0x0b',
        FIELDTERMINATOR ='0x0b',
        ROWTERMINATOR = '0x0b'
    ) WITH (
        doc VARCHAR(MAX)
    ) AS [result]


-- With Schema
SELECT 
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.Id') AS Id,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.FirstName') AS FirstName,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.LastName') AS LastName,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.CompanyName') AS CompanyName,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.Address.StreetName') AS StreetName,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.Address.Number') AS Number,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.Address.City') AS City,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.Address.Region') AS Region,
   JSON_VALUE(doc, '$.Address.Country') AS Country
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/json/customers*/*.json',
        FORMAT = 'CSV',
        FIELDQUOTE = '0x0b',
        FIELDTERMINATOR ='0x0b',
        ROWTERMINATOR = '0x0b'
    ) 
    WITH (
        doc VARCHAR(MAX)
    ) AS [result]

-- Simple
SELECT
    *
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/parquet/customers*.parquet',
        FORMAT = 'PARQUET'
    ) AS [result]

-- With Fields
SELECT
    Id,
    FirstName,
    LastName,
    CompanyName,
    JSON_VALUE(Address, '$.StreetName') AS StreetName,
    JSON_VALUE(Address, '$.Number') AS Number,
    JSON_VALUE(Address, '$.City') AS City,
    JSON_VALUE(Address, '$.Region') AS Region,
    JSON_VALUE(Address, '$.Country') AS Country
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/parquet/customers*.parquet',
        FORMAT = 'PARQUET'
    ) AS [result]

CREATE DATABASE SalesDB COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8

USE SalesDB

CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE csv
WITH (
    LOCATION='https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/'
)

-- Easier to query now
SELECT * 
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'customers*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'csv',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE,
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0'
) as customers

CREATE DATABASE SalesDB COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8

USE SalesDB

CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE csv
WITH (
    LOCATION='https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/'
)

-- Easier to query now
SELECT * 
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'customers.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'csv',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE,
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0'
) as customers

-- With Credentials
--DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE csv2
--DROP DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL sasToken

CREATE DATABASE SCOPED CREDENTIAL sasToken
WITH
    IDENTITY='SHARED ACCESS SIGNATURE',  
    SECRET = 'sp=r&st=2024-02-10T10:02:59Z&se=2024-03-02T18:02:59Z&spr=https&sv=2022-11-02&sr=d&sig=IuFXYZKkEVAu6Jta9wuq%2Fy7iC5WXynm3iODTcUv9zkM%3D&sdd=2';
GO

CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE csv2
WITH (
    LOCATION='https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/',
    CREDENTIAL=sasToken
)
GO;

SELECT * 
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'products*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'csv2',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE,
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0'
) as products

USE M2SalesDB;
GO;

DROP EXTERNAL TABLE Products
DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT FormatCsv

CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT FormatCsv
WITH (
 FORMAT_TYPE = DELIMITEDTEXT,
 FORMAT_OPTIONS (
    FIELD_TERMINATOR = ',',
    STRING_DELIMITER = '"',
    FIRST_ROW=2 -- Omit header row (1).
 )   
);

-- And now create a table

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE Products
(
    Id INT,
    BrandName VARCHAR(255),
    Name VARCHAR(255),
    Price DECIMAL(14, 10)
)
WITH
(
    LOCATION='products*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE=csv,
    FILE_FORMAT=FormatCsv
)

-- And do your queries
SELECT * FROM Products

--CREATE DATABASE SalesDB COLLATE Latin1_General_100_BIN2_UTF8
--USE SalesDB
--GO

DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE csv
CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE csv
WITH (
    LOCATION='https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/'
)

-- Test files and  paths
SELECT 
    cust.filepath() as path,
    cust.filename() as name
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'csv/*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'csv',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE,
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0'
) as cust

SELECT 
    cust.filepath() as path,
    cust.filename() as name,
    cust.filepath(1) as first,
    cust.filepath(2) as second
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'csv/*_*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'csv',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE,
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0'
) as cust

SELECT 
    cust.filepath() as path,
    cust.filepath(1) as first,
    cust.filepath(2) as second
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'csv/*_*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'csv',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE,
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0'
) as cust
WHERE cust.filepath(1) IN ('orders') AND cust.filepath(2) = 7

USE SalesDB
GO;

DROP EXTERNAL TABLE SalesOrders
DROP EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT FormatParquet
DROP EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE files
DROP PROCEDURE IF EXISTS sp_create_sales

USE SalesDB
GO;

CREATE EXTERNAL DATA SOURCE files
WITH(
    LOCATION = 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/'
    --TYPE = HADOOP -- Dedicated SQL Pool. TYPE = BLOB_STORAGE is wrong in Synapse
    --CREDENTIAL = cred
)

CREATE EXTERNAL FILE FORMAT FormatParquet
WITH (
    FORMAT_TYPE = PARQUET,
    DATA_COMPRESSION = 'org.apache.hadoop.io.compress.SnappyCodec'
)

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE SalesOrders
WITH
(
    LOCATION = 'parquet_orders/orders.parquet',
    DATA_SOURCE = files,
    FILE_FORMAT = FormatParquet
)
AS
SELECT Quantity, TotalPrice, ProductId
FROM OPENROWSET (
    BULK 'csv/orders*.csv',
    DATA_SOURCE = 'files',
    FORMAT = 'csv',
    PARSER_VERSION = '2.0',
    HEADER_ROW = TRUE
) AS datasource
---WHERE 

SELECT * FROM SalesOrders

USE SalesDB
GO;

CREATE PROCEDURE sp_create_sales @amount INT
AS
BEGIN
    IF EXISTS (SELECT * FROM sys.external_tables WHERE name='SalesOrders')
        DROP EXTERNAL TABLE SalesOrders
    
    CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE SalesOrders
    WITH
    (
        LOCATION = 'parquet_orders/orders.parquet', -- Make sure folders doesn't exist
        DATA_SOURCE = files,
        FILE_FORMAT = FormatParquet
    )
    AS
    SELECT Quantity, TotalPrice, ProductId
    FROM OPENROWSET (
        BULK 'csv/orders*.csv',
        DATA_SOURCE = 'files',
        FORMAT = 'csv',
        PARSER_VERSION = '2.0',
        HEADER_ROW = TRUE
    ) AS datasource
END

--EXEC sp_create_sales 100

-- Next see Integrate Mod22UseStoredProcedure

-- If you're connected to GitHub make sure your working in Live Mode
-- Check dropdown in top lef dropdown!
-- Lots of things won't work in GitHub mode
-- No Problems yet

-- Generate From Template
-- Manually
-- 1) Create Database
-- 2) Create ***Table from Data Lake***. Make sure input folder points to an existing folder where the data is in
-- 3) Create Custom. Make sure input folder points to an existing FILE!!!! You cannot select a file >:-( 
-- 4) Map Data. Would be nice if it works.

USE M2SalesLake
GO

SELECT * FROM Customers

SELECT o.TotalPrice, p.BrandName, p.Name, c.LastName
FROM Orders As o
JOIN Products As p ON p.Id = o.ProductId
JOIN Customers As c ON c.Id = o.CustomerId

SELECT SUM(o.TotalPrice), p.Name
FROM Orders As o
JOIN Products As p ON p.Id = o.ProductId
JOIN Customers As c ON c.Id = o.CustomerId
GROUP BY p.Name

SELECT SUM(o.TotalPrice), CONCAT(c.FirstName, ' ', c.LastName)
FROM Orders As o
JOIN Products As p ON p.Id = o.ProductId
JOIN Customers As c ON c.Id = o.CustomerId
GROUP BY c.FirstName, c.LastName


-- This cannot be done with EXTERNAL TABLES. Using Spark pool however you can
INSERT INTO Products (Id, BrandName, Name, Price) VALUES (1000, 'OPPO', 'BDB-100', 800)

-- Schema on which analysis takes place
CREATE SCHEMA Main;
GO;

-- Schema for preparing data
-- Staging tables are used as temporary storage for data as it's being loaded into the data warehouse. 
-- A typical pattern is to structure the table to make it as efficient as possible to ingest the data from 
-- its external source (often files in a data lake) into the relational database, and then use SQL statements 
-- to load the data from the staging tables into the dimension and fact tables.
CREATE SCHEMA Staging
GO;

-- Create Tables for Main schema
-- Dedicated SQL pools in Synapse Analytics don't support foreign key and unique constraints as found in other relational database systems
-- INDEXES
-- While Synapse Analytics dedicated SQL pools support clustered indexes as found in SQL Server, the default index type is clustered columnstore. 
-- This index type offers a significant performance advantage when querying large quantities of data in a typical data warehouse schema and should be used where possible
-- DISTRIBUTION
-- Azure Synapse Analytics dedicated SQL pools use a massively parallel processing (MPP) architecture, as opposed to the symmetric multiprocessing (SMP) 
-- architecture used in most OLTP database systems. In an MPP system, the data in a table is distributed for processing across a pool of nodes. 
-- Synapse Analytics supports the following kinds of distribution:
-- * Hash: A deterministic hash value is calculated for the specified column and used to assign the row to a compute node.
-- * Round-robin: Rows are distributed evenly across all compute nodes.
-- * Replicated: A copy of the table is stored on each compute node.

-- Dimension tables
-- Dimension tables describe business entities, such as products, people, places, and dates. 
-- A dimension table contains a unique key column that uniquely identifies each row in the table. 
-- In fact, it's common for a dimension table to include two key columns:
-- * a surrogate key that is specific to the data warehouse and uniquely identifies each row in the dimension table in the data warehouse - usually an incrementing integer number.
-- * an alternate key, often a natural or business key that is used to identify a specific instance of an entity in the transactional source system from which the entity record originated
--   - such as a product code or a customer ID.


-- We use the SNOWFLAKE strategy here
-- We could also use the STAR strategy
CREATE TABLE Main.DimCustomers
(
    Id BIGINT IDENTITY NOT NULL,
    AlternateKey BIGINT NULL,
    FirstName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    LastName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    CompanyName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    StreetName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Number INT NOT NULL,
    GeoId BIGINT NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Main.DimGeo
(
    Id BIGINT IDENTITY NOT NULL,
    City NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Region NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Country NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Main.DimBrands
(
    Id BIGINT IDENTITY NOT NULL,
    [Name] NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Main.DimProducts
(
    Id BIGINT IDENTITY NOT NULL,
    AlternateKey BIGINT NULL,
    BrandId BIGINT NOT NULL,
    [Name] NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Price DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Main.DimDates
( 
    Id INT NOT NULL,
    AltKey DATETIME NOT NULL,
    DayOfMonth INT NOT NULL,
    DayOfWeek INT NOT NULL,
    DayName NVARCHAR(15) NOT NULL,
    MonthOfYear INT NOT NULL,
    MonthName NVARCHAR(15) NOT NULL,
    CalendarQuarter INT  NOT NULL,
    CalendarYear INT NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Main.FactOrders
(
    Id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    OrderDateId INT NOT NULL,
    CustomerId BIGINT NOT NULL,
    ProductId BIGINT NOT NULL,
    Quantity INT NOT NULL,
    TotalPrice DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = HASH(Id),
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

-- Create Staging tables
-- Staging tables are used as temporary storage for data as it's being loaded into the data warehouse. 
-- A typical pattern is to structure the table to make it as efficient as possible to ingest the data from its 
-- external source (often files in a data lake) into the relational database, and then use SQL statements to 
-- load the data from the staging tables into the dimension and fact tables.
--
-- In Some case you might consider using External Tables.
-- Products table might be a good option as a external table

CREATE TABLE Staging.DimCustomers
(
    Id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    AlternateKey BIGINT NULL,
    FirstName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    LastName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    CompanyName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    StreetName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Number INT NOT NULL,
    GeoId BIGINT NULL,  -- Needs to be populated later
    City NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Region NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Country NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Staging.DimProducts
(
    Id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    AlternateKey BIGINT NULL,
    BrandId BIGINT NULL,
    BrandName NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    [Name] NVARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    Price DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = REPLICATE,
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

CREATE TABLE Staging.FactOrders
(
    Id BIGINT NOT NULL,
    OrderDate DATETIME2 NOT NULL,
    OrderDateId INT NULL,
    CustomerId BIGINT NOT NULL,
    ProductId BIGINT NOT NULL,
    Quantity INT NOT NULL,
    TotalPrice DECIMAL(10,2) NOT NULL
    
)
WITH
(
    DISTRIBUTION = HASH(Id),
    CLUSTERED COLUMNSTORE INDEX
);

COPY INTO Staging.DimProducts
(Id 1, BrandName 2, Name 3, Price 4)
FROM 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/products*.csv'
WITH
(
	FILE_TYPE = 'CSV'
	,MAXERRORS = 0
	,FIRSTROW = 2
	,ERRORFILE = 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/errors'
    ,IDENTITY_INSERT = 'OFF'
)
GO;

COPY INTO Staging.DimCustomers
(Id 1, FirstName 2, LastName 3, CompanyName 4, StreetName 5, Number 6, City 7, Region 8, Country 9)
FROM 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/customers_*.csv'
WITH
(
	FILE_TYPE = 'CSV'
	,MAXERRORS = 0
	,FIRSTROW = 2
	,ERRORFILE = 'https://4dnsynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/errors'
    ,IDENTITY_INSERT = 'OFF'
)
GO;

COPY INTO Staging.FactOrders
(Id 1,  Quantity 2, TotalPrice 3, OrderDate 4, CustomerId 5, ProductId 6)
FROM 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/testdata/csv/orders_*.csv'
WITH
(
	FILE_TYPE = 'CSV'
	,MAXERRORS = 0
	,FIRSTROW = 2
	,ERRORFILE = 'https://pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/files/'
)
GO

-- Next Update DimTables and update staging
-- First the DimDates table. Can be time consuming
-- Temp tables are really temp. Will be gone after execution so select the whole statment (better us this in a stored procedure)
CREATE TABLE #TmpStageDate (DateVal DATE NOT NULL)

-- Populate the temp table with a range of dates
DECLARE @StartDate DATE;
DECLARE @EndDate DATE;
SET @StartDate='2019-01-01';
SET @EndDate=GETDATE();
DECLARE @LoopDate DATE = @StartDate;
WHILE @LoopDate<=@EndDate
BEGIN
    INSERT INTO #TmpStageDate VALUES
    (
        @LoopDate
    )
    SET @LoopDate = DATEADD(dd, 1, @LoopDate)
END
--SELECT * FROM #TmpStageDate

-- Insert the dates and calculated attributes into the dimension table
INSERT INTO Main.DimDates
SELECT CAST(CONVERT(VARCHAR(8), DateVal, 112) as INT), -- date key
    DateVal, --date alt key
    Day(DateVal), -- day number of month
    DATEPART(WEEKDAY, DateVal),
	DATENAME(WEEKDAY, DateVal),
	DATEPART(MONTH, DateVal),
	DATENAME(MONTH, DateVal),
	DATEPART(QUARTER, DateVal),
	DATEPART(YEAR, DateVal)
FROM #TmpStageDate
GO

DROP TABLE #TmpStageDate

-- Now the DimGeo table
INSERT INTO Main.DimGeo
SELECT DISTINCT City, Region, Country FROM Staging.DimCustomers

-- The DimBrands
INSERT INTO Main.DimBrands
SELECT DISTINCT BrandName FROM Staging.DimProducts

UPDATE Staging.DimCustomers
SET GeoId = Main.DimGeo.Id, AlternateKey = Staging.DimCustomers.Id
FROM Staging.DimCustomers
INNER JOIN Main.DimGeo ON Staging.DimCustomers.City = Main.DimGeo.City

-- Cusomers is ready. Move data to Main
INSERT INTO Main.DimCustomers
SELECT Id, AlternateKey, FirstName, LastName, CompanyName, StreetName, Number, GeoId FROM Staging.DimCustomers

UPDATE Staging.DimProducts
SET BrandId = Main.DimBrands.Id, AlternateKey = Staging.DimProducts.Id
FROM Staging.DimProducts
INNER JOIN Main.DimBrands ON Staging.DimProducts.BrandName = Main.DimBrands.Name

-- Products is ready. Move data to Main scheme
INSERT INTO Main.DimProducts
SELECT Id, AlternateKey, BrandId, Name, Price FROM Staging.DimProducts

-- Next update the staging FactOrders table
-- Make sure the foreign keys reflect the IDENTITY columns in Main scheme
UPDATE Staging.FactOrders 
SET OrderDateId = Main.DimDates.Id, CustomerId = Main.DimCustomers.Id, ProductId = Main.DimProducts.Id
FROM Staging.FactOrders
INNER JOIN Main.DimDates ON CAST(Staging.FactOrders.OrderDate AS DATE) = CAST(Main.DimDates.AltKey AS DATE)
INNER JOIN Main.DimCustomers ON Staging.FactOrders.CustomerId = Main.DimCustomers.AlternateKey
INNER JOIN Main.DimProducts ON Staging.FactOrders.ProductId = Main.DimProducts.AlternateKey

-- Finally Copy the data
INSERT INTO Main.FactOrders
SELECT Id, OrderDateId, CustomerId, ProductId, Quantity, TotalPrice  FROM Staging.FactOrders

-- DO NOT EXECUTE. FOR EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES

-- Build queries depending on the change frequency
-- Type 0. Dimension cannot change
-- Type 1. Changes in place. Old data is gone
-- Type 2. Changes result in new dimension row. Usually requires an addidional column

-- Type 1 & 2
-- New Customers
INSERT INTO Main.DimCustomers
SELECT stg.*
FROM Staging.DimCustomers AS stg
WHERE NOT EXISTS
    (SELECT * FROM Main.DimCustomers AS dim
    WHERE dim.AlternateKey = stg.AlternateKey)

-- Type 1 updates (name)
UPDATE Main.DimCustomers
SET CompanyName = stg.CompanyName
FROM Staging.DimCustomers AS stg
WHERE Main.DimCustomers.AlternateKey = stg.AlternateKey

-- Type 2 updates (StreetName)
INSERT INTO Main.DimCustomers
SELECT stg.*
FROM Staging.DimCustomers AS stg
JOIN Main.DimCustomers AS dim
ON stg.AlternateKey = dim.AlternateKey
AND stg.StreetName <> dim.StreetName;

-- Alternatively

MERGE Main.DimProducts AS tgt
    USING (SELECT * FROM Staging.DimProducts) AS src
    ON src.AlternateKey = tgt.AlternateKey
WHEN MATCHED THEN
    -- Type 1 updates
    UPDATE SET
        tgt.Name = src.Name,
        tgt.Price = src.Price,
        tgt.BrandId = src.BrandId
WHEN NOT MATCHED THEN
    -- New products
    INSERT VALUES
        (
            src.AlternateKey,
            src.Name,
            src.BrandId,
        );

-- And rebuild the indexes for performance

ALTER INDEX ALL ON Main.DimProducts REBUILD
ALTER INDEX ALL ON Main.DimCustomers REBUILD
ALTER INDEX ALL ON Main.FactOrders REBUILD

-- Check stats
CREATE STATISTICS productcategory_stats
ON Main.FactOrders(OrderDateId);

source: # Query External Data using Spark Pool

### My First Dataframe
Dataframes are the heart of spark notebooks.
They have two types of operations: 
- Transformations. Like select(), where(), withColumn() 
- Actions. Like count(), collect(), show()

Actions will fetch the data.
Transformations will not

df = spark.sql(f"SELECT * FROM {lakedb}.Customers")
schema = "StreetName STRING, Number INT, City STRING, Region STRING, Country STRING"
#parsed_df = df.withColumn("Address", from_json(col("Address"), schema))
df.printSchema()
df.show(truncate=True)

_data = [
    [0,"Menno","Wal","Ven Online",'{"StreetName":"Emmakade","Number":92,"City":"Breda","Region":"Noord Brabant","Country":"Nederland"}'],
    [1,"Xavier","Jong","Vries N.V.",'{"StreetName":"Basrijk","Number":85,"City":"Utrecht","Region":"Utrecht","Country":"Nederland"}']
]
# Columns for the data
_cols = ['Id', 'FirstName', 'LastName', 'CompanyName', 'Address']
# Lets create the raw Data Frame
df_raw = spark.createDataFrame(data = _data, schema = _cols)

schema = "StreetName STRING, Number INT, City STRING, Region STRING, Country STRING"
df = df_raw.withColumn("Address", from_json(col("Address"), schema))
df.printSchema()
df.show()
###### Will only work if data is in parquet format and the external table is not assigned to a single file
INSERT INTO M2SalesLake.Products (Id, BrandName, Name, Price) VALUES (1000, 'OPPO', 'BDB-100', 800)

%%sql
SELECT SUM(o.TotalPrice), p.Name
FROM M2SalesLake.Orders As o
JOIN M2SalesLake.Products As p ON p.Id = o.ProductId
JOIN M2SalesLake.Customers As c ON c.Id = o.CustomerId
GROUP BY p.Name

### My First Dataframe
Dataframes are the heart of spark notebooks.
They have two types of operations: 
- Transformations. Like select(), where(), withColumn() 
- Actions. Like count(), collect(), show()

Actions will fetch the data.

Transformations will not.

More operations [Here](https://api-docs.databricks.com/python/pyspark/latest/pyspark.sql/dataframe.html)

from pyspark.sql.functions import *

#dataarray = from_json("", "{'www':'vvv'}")
#print(dataarray)

_data = [
    [0,"Menno","Wal","Ven Online",'{"StreetName":"Emmakade","Number":92,"City":"Breda","Region":"Noord Brabant","Country":"Nederland"}'],
    [1,"Xavier","Jong","Vries N.V.",'{"StreetName":"Basrijk","Number":85,"City":"Utrecht","Region":"Utrecht","Country":"Nederland"}']
]
# Columns for the data
_cols = ['Id', 'FirstName', 'LastName', 'CompanyName', 'Address']
# Lets create the raw Data Frame
df_raw = spark.createDataFrame(data = _data, schema = _cols)
#df_raw.printSchema()
#display(df_raw)

schema = "StreetName STRING, Number INT, City STRING, Region STRING, Country STRING"
df = df_raw.withColumn("Address", from_json(col("Address"), schema))
df.printSchema()
display(df)
#df.show()
You can find the abfss path in the datalake on the file properties

%%pyspark
df = spark.read.load(lakepath + 'csv/customers*.csv', format='csv', header=True)
df.printSchema()
display(df)

from pyspark.sql.types import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

addressSchema = StructType([
    StructField("StreetName", StringType()),
    StructField("Number", IntegerType()),
    StructField("City", StringType()),
    StructField("Region", StringType()),
    StructField("Country", StringType())
])

tableSchema = StructType([
    StructField("Id", IntegerType()),
    StructField("FirstName", StringType()),
    StructField("LastName", StringType()),
    StructField("CompanyName", StringType()),

])

from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from matplotlib import pyplot

spark.conf.set('spark.sql.parquet.int96RebaseModeInRead', 'CORRECTED') # TimeStamp Issues
df = spark.read.load(lakepath + "parquet/orders*.parquet", format="parquet")
dfproducts = spark.read.load(lakepath + "parquet/products*.parquet", format="parquet")

df = df.select("Quantity", "TotalPrice", "ProductId")
df = df.join(dfproducts, df.ProductId == dfproducts.Id)

df1 = df.select("TotalPrice", col("BrandName").alias("Brand")) \
    .groupBy("Brand").agg(sum("TotalPrice").alias("Total"))
df1 = df1.orderBy(col("Total").desc())


df2 = df.select("Quantity", col("BrandName").alias("Brand")) \
    .groupBy("Brand").agg(sum("Quantity").alias("Quantity"))
df2 = df2.orderBy(col("Quantity").desc())

# First create a pandas frame
df1 = df1.limit(10).toPandas()
df2 = df2.limit(10).toPandas()


# Clear plot area
pyplot.clf()

fig, figs = pyplot.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(10,4))
pyplot.title("Sales Insights")
figs[0].barh(y=df1.Brand, width=df1.Total, color="red")
figs[0].set_title("Total sales by brand")

figs[1].pie(df2.Quantity, labels=df2.Brand, autopct="%1d")
figs[1].set_title("Amounts by Brand")


pyplot.show()

## Partition Data

PySpark Date and Timestamp Functions are supported on DataFrame and SQL queries and they work similarly to traditional SQL, Date and Time are very important if you are using PySpark for ETL. Most of all these functions accept input as, Date type, Timestamp type, or String. If a String used, it should be in a default format that can be cast to date.

- DateType default format is yyyy-MM-dd 
- TimestampType default format is yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSSS
- Returns null if the input is a string that can not be cast to Date or Timestamp.
[Date and Timestamp functions](https://sparkbyexamples.com/pyspark/pyspark-sql-date-and-timestamp-functions/)

from pyspark.sql.functions import *

df = spark.read.csv(lakepath + 'csv/orders*.csv', header=True, inferSchema=True)
# DateTime is en-US format (C#) so convert it first
dated = df.withColumn("OrderDateTS", to_timestamp(col("OrderDate"), "MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss"))
dated = dated.drop("OrderDate")
dated = dated.withColumn("Year", year(col("OrderDateTS"))) \
    .withColumn("Month", month(col("OrderDateTS")))

display(dated)

dated.write.partitionBy("Year", "Month").mode("overwrite").parquet(lakepath + "/partition_data")

## Define Table and Views (unmanaged)

External tables are "loosely bound" to the underlying files and deleting the table does not delete the files. This allows you to use Spark to do the heavy lifting of transformation then persist the data in the lake. After this is done you can drop the table and downstream processes can access these optimized structures. You can also define managed tables, for which the underlying data files are stored in an internally managed storage location associated with the metastore. Managed tables are "tightly-bound" to the files, and dropping a managed table deletes the associated files.

Managed tables can only be delta tables

### Create simple (external) table

Check underlying file system

from pyspark.sql.functions import *

df = spark.read.csv(lakepath + 'csv/orders*.csv', header=True, inferSchema=True)
df = df.withColumn("OrderDateTS", to_timestamp(col("OrderDate"), "MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss"))
df.write.saveAsTable("salesorders", path=lakepath + "/sales/orders", format="parquet", mode="overwrite")

dfr = spark.read.table("salesorders")
display(dfr)
### Read from simple table using sql

tran = spark.sql("SELECT *, YEAR(OrderDateTS) AS Year, MONTH(OrderDateTS) AS MONTH FROM salesorders")
tran.write.partitionBy("Year", "Month") \
    .saveAsTable("transorders", path=lakepath+"/tranorders", format="parquet", mode="overwrite")
SELECT * FROM transorders WHERE Year = 2021 AND Month=1

## Drop the tables

Will not delete the files in the datalake

customers = spark.read.load(lakepath+"csv/customers*.csv", format="csv", header=True)
orders = spark.read.load(lakepath+"csv/orders*.csv", format="csv", header=True)
products = spark.read.load(lakepath+"csv/prod*.csv", format="csv", header=True)

# mode("append") add to existing files
customers.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").save(lakepath + deltapath + "customers")
orders.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").save(lakepath + deltapath + "orders")
products.write.format("delta").mode("overwrite").save(lakepath + deltapath + "products")

from delta.tables import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

deltaTable = DeltaTable.forPath(spark, lakepath + deltapath + "products")

# Update the table
deltaTable.update(
    condition = "Id == 101",
    set = { "Price": "1.0" })

df = spark.read.format("delta").load(lakepath + deltapath + "products").where("Id == 101")
display(df)

## timestampAsOf can be used too
df = spark.read.format("delta").option("versionAsOf", 0).load(lakepath + deltapath + "products").where("Id == 101")
display(df)

SELECT * FROM delta.`abfss://files@pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/testdata/deltabase/products` WHERE Id=0
-- Not supported for unmanaged

%%sql
SELECT orders.Quantity, customers.LastName FROM delta.`abfss://files@pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/testdata/deltabase/orders` AS orders
JOIN delta.`abfss://files@pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/testdata/deltabase/customers` AS customers ON orders.CustomerId = customers.Id

# Delta Lake Tables
The benefits of using Delta Lake in a Synapse Analytics Spark pool include:

- Relational tables that support querying and data modification. With Delta Lake, you can store data in tables that support CRUD (create, read, update, and delete) operations. In other words, you can select, insert, update, and delete rows of data in the same way you would in a relational database system.
- Support for ACID transactions. Relational databases are designed to support transactional data modifications that provide atomicity (transactions complete as a single unit of work), consistency (transactions leave the database in a consistent state), isolation (in-process transactions can't interfere with one another), and durability (when a transaction completes, the changes it made are persisted). Delta Lake brings this same transactional support to Spark by implementing a transaction log and enforcing serializable isolation for concurrent operations.
- Data versioning and time travel. Because all transactions are logged in the transaction log, you can track multiple versions of each table row and even use the time travel feature to retrieve a previous version of a row in a query.
- Support for batch and streaming data. While most relational databases include tables that store static data, Spark includes native support for streaming data through the Spark Structured Streaming API. Delta Lake tables can be used as both sinks (destinations) and sources for streaming data.
- Standard formats and interoperability. The underlying data for Delta Lake tables is stored in Parquet format, which is commonly used in data lake ingestion pipelines. Additionally, you can use the serverless SQL pool in Azure Synapse Analytics to query Delta Lake tables in SQL.
You recognize managed table by the missing file path. They are created for you

customersdf = spark.read.load(lakepath+"csv/customers*.csv", format="csv", header=True)
ordersdf = spark.read.load(lakepath+"csv/orders*.csv", format="csv", header=True)

# Unmanaged Table. It specifies a file path
customersdf.write.format("delta").option("path", lakepath + deltapath + "customers").saveAsTable("customers")
ordersdf.write.format("delta").option("path", lakepath + deltapath + "orders").saveAsTable("orders")

# Managed Table
customersdf.write.format("delta").saveAsTable("man_customers")
ordersdf.write.format("delta").saveAsTable("man_orders")

%%sql
SELECT * FROM man_orders AS o
JOIN  man_customers AS c ON o.CustomerId = c.Id

from delta.tables import *

DeltaTable.create(spark) \
    .tableName("man_people") \
        .addColumn("Id", "BIGINT", nullable=False) \
        .addColumn("Name", "STRING", nullable=False) \
        .addColumn("Age", "INT") \
        .execute()

from delta.tables import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

deltaPeople = DeltaTable.forName(spark, "man_people")
schema = deltaPeople.toDF().schema

# Method 1
data = [(1, "Kees", 56)]
df = spark.createDataFrame(data, schema)
df.write.format("delta").mode("append").saveAsTable("man_people")

display(deltaPeople)

# Method 2
df1 = spark.createDataFrame([(2, "Iris", 24)], schema)
df1.write.insertInto("man_people", overwrite=False)

display(deltaPeople)

# Method 3
spark.sql("INSERT INTO man_people (Id, Name, Age) VALUES (3, 'Rene', 45)")
display(deltaPeople)

deltaPeople.update(col("Id") == 1, set={"Name":lit("Cornelis")})

deltaPeople = DeltaTable.forName(spark, "man_people")

deltaPeople.delete(col("Id") == 1)

display(deltaPeople.toDF())
### More commonly you'll use some kind of merge

from delta.tables import *
from pyspark.sql.functions import *

deltaPeople = DeltaTable.forName(spark, "man_people")
schema = deltaPeople.toDF().schema

data = [(2, "Kees", 56), (6, "Herman", 34), (7, "Tinie", 56), (3, "Guus", 67)]
df = spark.createDataFrame(data, schema)

deltaPeople.alias("main").merge(df.alias("upd"), "main.Id = upd.Id") \
    .whenMatchedUpdate(set={"Name":"upd.Name", "Age":"upd.Age"}) \
    .whenNotMatchedInsert(values={"Id": "upd.Id", "Name": "upd.Name", "Age":"upd.Age"}) \
    .execute()

display(deltaPeople.toDF())
### You can query delta tables on serveless pool
This query can be generated from the delta table folder

%%sql
SELECT
    TOP 100 *
FROM
    OPENROWSET(
        BULK 'abfss://files@pssynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/testdata/deltabase/customers/',
        FORMAT = 'DELTA'
    ) AS [result]

import com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics
from com.microsoft.spark.sqlanalytics.Constants import Constants
from pyspark.sql.functions import *
from pyspark.sql.types import *

orderspath = 'abfss://files@4dnsynapselake.dfs.core.windows.net/sales_small/csv/orders_*.csv'
stagingOrders = 'sqlpool.Staging.FactOrders2'

dimCustomers = spark.read.synapsesql("sqlpool.Main.DimCustomers").withColumnRenamed("Id", "CustId")
dimProducts = spark.read.synapsesql("sqlpool.Main.DimProducts").withColumnRenamed("Id", "ProdId")
dimDates = spark.read.synapsesql("sqlpool.Main.DimDates").withColumnRenamed("Id", "DateId")

#display(dimDates.limit(5))
ordersCsv = spark.read \
    .load(orderspath, format="csv", inferSchema=True, header=True)

ordersCsv = ordersCsv.withColumn("OrderDate", to_date(col("OrderDate"), "MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss"))


# broadcast join if dimtable is small (typically 10M). The dimtable will be copied to each node.
ordersCsv = ordersCsv.join(broadcast(dimDates), ordersCsv.OrderDate == dimDates.AltKey, "inner").withColumn("OrderDateId", col("DateId"))
# use regular join if dimtable is huge
# ordersCsv = ordersCsv.join(imDates, ordersCsv.OrderDate == dimDates.AltKey).withColumn("OrderDateId", col("DateId"))

#print(ordersCsv.schema)
# Fix type guesses
ordersCsv = ordersCsv \
    .withColumn("Id", col("Id").cast(LongType())) \
    .withColumn("OrderDate", col("OrderDate").cast(TimestampType())) \
    .withColumn("CustomerId", col("CustomerId").cast(LongType())) \
    .withColumn("ProductId", col("ProductId").cast(LongType())) \
    .withColumn("TotalPrice", col("TotalPrice").cast(DecimalType(10, 2)))
#print(ordersCsv.schema)
ordersCsv = ordersCsv.select("Id", "OrderDate", "OrderDateId", "CustomerId", "ProductId", "Quantity", "TotalPrice")

ordersCsv = ordersCsv \
    .join(dimCustomers, ordersCsv.CustomerId == dimCustomers.AlternateKey) \
    .join(dimProducts, ordersCsv.ProductId == dimProducts.AlternateKey) \
    .withColumn("ProductId", col("ProdId")) \
    .withColumn("CustomerId", col("CustId")) \
    .select("Id", "OrderDate", "OrderDateId", "CustomerId", "ProductId", "Quantity", "TotalPrice")

display(ordersCsv.limit(5))

# mode override drops te old table and recreated a new one
# mode append appends data to existing table
ordersCsv.write.mode("overwrite").synapsesql(stagingOrders, Constants.INTERNAL)
